summary: The document provides a detailed biographical profile of Robert Malcolm Keith, highlighting his early life, military service in the US Navy from 1945 to 1946, and his extensive career with the CIA starting in 1947. It outlines his various roles within the CIA, including Intel Asst, I.O., and Ops Off, and his involvement in significant Cold War-era intelligence activities, particularly in China and Indonesia. Notably, Keith played a key role during and after the abortive coup attempt in Indonesia in September 1965, for which he received commendations. The document's inclusion in the records released under the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act of 1992 underscores its historical significance and relevance to research on intelligence activities during that period.
key_findings: Robert Malcolm Keith was born on August 11, 1927.
He served in the US Navy from 1945 to 1946.
Keith had a long career with the CIA, starting in 1947, with various positions including Intel Asst, I.O., and Ops Off.
He was involved in operations related to China, Indonesia, and other regions, showcasing his role in Cold War-era intelligence activities.
Keith received commendations for his service, particularly for his role during and after the abortive coup attempt in Indonesia in September 1965.

The document is part of the records released under the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act of 1992, highlighting its relevance to historical research on intelligence activities during that era.
keywords: President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act
